title: Pushkar Camel Fair
short_description: A vibrant mix of a livestock fair and a holy pilgrimage, set in the desert town of Pushkar, Rajasthan.
long_description:
The Pushkar Camel Fair (Pushkar Mela) is one of the world's largest livestock fairs. For five days, the dunes around the holy town of Pushkar are taken over by 50,000 camels and livestock, brought by turbaned traders for sale. It is a photographer's paradise.

But it is not just commerce; it is a carnival. There are 'Matka Phod' competitions, 'Longest Moustache' contests, and camel races. Simultaneously, it is a devout pilgrimage. Pushkar is one of the few places with a temple dedicated to Lord Brahma. On Kartik Purnima, thousands of devotees wash away their sins in the sacred Pushkar Lake. The contrast between the dusty, noisy trade fair and the serene, chanting-filled ghats is what makes Pushkar unique.
significance: A livestock trade fair coinciding with a holy pilgrimage to the Brahma Temple.
key_rituals: Holy Dip: Bathing in Pushkar Lake on full moon day.
Camel Trading: Buying and selling of decorated livestock.
Competitions: Turban tying, moustache, and bridal competitions.
Deepdaan: Floating lamps on the lake.

top_places.title: Pushkar, Rajasthan
top_places.best_to_experience: Staying in a luxury tent city near the Mela grounds.
top_places.how_to_reach: Train to Ajmer (30 mins away) or Fly to Jaipur (2 hrs away).

practical_info.dress_tips: It gets chilly in the desert at night. Bring layers. Daytimes are sunny and dusty.
practical_info.safety_tips: Beware of touts and aggressive beggars. Agree on prices for photos with sadhus/camels beforehand.
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Sand makes it impossible for wheelchairs.

faqs.a: Yes, Pushkar is a holy town. No meat or alcohol is served within city limits.

faqs.q: When is the best time for photography?
faqs.a: Early morning (sunrise) and sunset when the dust kicked up by camels creates a golden haze.
